We've all complained about it at one time or another: another Hollywood remake, another sequel, another predictable and formulaic story, or worse, plotholes you can drive a semi through! "No one in that position would ever..." What? Run in heels? Split up in a scary situation? Ask "what do we do now?" or make an asinine decision based solely on being "pure of heart." We've all been there too many times to count. So, what's the solution? Start making your OWN movies! Tell YOUR stories! It's easier than you think: https://lnkd.in/gEWEB5pq

Greetings! DEADPOOL & WOLVERINE continued to sizzle in theatres, bringing in an additional $97M in its second weekend. The Marvel superhero sequel has grossed $395M in its first 10 days, making it the second highest earning movie of 2024 behind Pixar‚Äôs INSIDE OUT 2 which has earned $627M since its June 14th opening. In fact, the R-rated DEADPOOL & WOLVERINE has earned more than the PG-rated INSIDE OUT 2 had at the same point in its release. The latest Mad Max movie is turning out to be a major disappointment. In fact, its opening marked the worst Memorial Day weekend box office in 30 years. Read any of the press coverage, and you'll be led to believe that this is a movie industry problem. It's not. I wanted to go see the new Mad Max film on Memorial Day weekend. I loved the last Mad Max film, I think the world of Anya Taylor-Joy, and this film is getting respectable reviews. So why didn't I go see it? Because I was at home watching homemade Minecraft videos on YouTube with a 6-year old. Which illustrates three points: 1) Movies are competing for attention with other mediums that aren't movies. 2) Movies aren't just competing for attention against big budget production houses; they're also competing against everyday people who create low-budget content. 3) Movies aren't just competing against new content for attention. They're also competing against the archives. (Minecraft is 15 years old!) The media thinks in media verticals, so it labels Furiosa's failure as a "movie industry" problem. But it's not a movie industry problem, just like it's not a radio industry problem, a TV industry problem, a podcasting problem, a newspaper problem, or a journalism problem. It's a media industry problem. There's too much content out there. We're going to need to find something else to monetize. #mediaindustry #communitybuilding

Inside a seemingly ordinary house, a little girl quietly crawls towards a flickering TV screen and whispers words that still send chills down our spines: ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre here...‚Äù Yes, this is the house from the cult classic "Poltergeist" (1982). This home, located at 4267 Roxbury St. in Simi Valley, was personally chosen by Steven Spielberg during filming. He wanted the horrors to unfold in a familiar, everyday setting, and this house was the perfect fit. üè° During filming, the entire neighborhood was engulfed in true mystique: artificial corpses scattered around, movie hearses lining the streets ‚Äî the neighbors never knew what to expect next. And inside this house, scenes were shot that would go down in cinema history. Now, 45 years later, this house is back on the market. But it‚Äôs not just a piece of real estate; it‚Äôs a piece of Hollywood history. Even decades later, fans of "Poltergeist" continue to visit to see where their favorite scenes were filmed. But the real question is: are you ready to peek behind the facade and discover what‚Äôs there now?
